awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Nanostructural Stability of Alkali-Activated (N,K)-ASH Geopolymer Cements for Sustainable and Resilient Civil Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
This research aims to enhance infrastructure sustainability by advancing the materials science of alternative cementitious materials that reduce ecological impacts associated with Portland cement manufacture. The results from this work, which concerns the long-term durability of novel geopolymer cements, should aid in ensuring the resiliency and service-life performance of next-generation civil infrastructure construction materials. Furthermore, this research aims to lay the technical foundation for the science and engineering of novel waste- and stormwater infrastructure construction materials that leverage the pollutant removal potentials of secondary (zeolitic) structures that may form in alkali-activated materials. Manufacture of portland cement is responsible for approximately 8 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions. While preliminary research by the PI (and others) has shown that fly ash- and metakaolin-based alkali-activated geopolymer cements can provide a durable, low-carbon alternative to Portland cement (especially for water infrastructure applications), the actual physical and chemical degradation mechanisms of (N,K)-ASH gels in geopolymer cements are poorly understood. Understanding and controlling these mechanisms is a vital next step to ensure both the sustainability and long-term durability of geopolymer-based cementitious materials prior to their widespread use in civil infrastructure applications. 

The specific objective of this research is to investigate the time-dependent stability of (N,K)-ASH geopolymer gel nanostructures in the presence of both physical and chemical environmental stressors. Fundamental knowledge on the nanostructural stability of (N,K)-ASH gels is necessary to produce sustainable, durable geopolymer-based alternatives to conventional portland cement. The research program is organized into three experimental phases. In Phase I, the structure and properties of synthetic (N,K)-ASH geopolymer gels will be characterized at the nano-, micro-, and mesoscale. In Phase II, atomic-scale degradation of (N,K)-ASH gels in the presence of (1) deionized water, (2) carbon dioxide, and (3) acidic media will be investigated using a combination of magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, and quantitative x-ray diffraction. In Phase III, the physical and chemical degradation of metakaolin-based (N,K)-ASH gels will be investigated and compared
to the atomic-scale changes observed in pure (N,K)-ASH geopolymer gels.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the time-dependent stability of low-calcium alkali-activated (i.e., geopolymer) cements in the presence of physical and chemical environmental stressors. The primary outcome of this project concerns the formulation and experimental validation of a new mechanism for the sulfuric acid degradation of low-calcium alkali-activated cements (AACs). The new mechanism, termed “cationic stabilization,” involves increased nanostructural stability of the aluminosilicate binder by polyvalent cationic metals, like iron, magnesium, and other heavy metals, like copper and cobalt. Experimental results substantiate that inclusion of these metals yields higher stability of AACs upon exposure to sulfuric acid. A secondary outcome of this project concerns new knowledge on the early-age nanostructural stability of low-calcium alkali-activated cements (AACs). More specifically, the process-structure-property relationships were studied by varying significant processing factors, mainly: (1) alkali content, (2) silica availability, and (3) curing time. Experimental results demonstrate that these factors dictate zeolite mineralization (e.g., nucleation, growth, metastability) in low-calcium AACs. This work also showed that zeolite formation can be explicitly controlled and directed by using structure-directing agents. These agents control and induce favorable mineral formation that lead to increased durability of low-calcium AACs.

The results from this project has led to the development of new material technologies that will enhance infrastructure sustainability and durability by advancing the materials science of alternative cementitious materials that reduce ecological impacts associated with ordinary portland cement manufacture. The manufacture of portland cement is responsible for approximately 8 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions. The results from this work, which concerns the long-term durability of novel low-calcium geopolymer cements, aided by generating new knowledge on materials processing, resiliency, and service-life performance of next-generation civil infrastructure materials with potentially lower environmental footprints. Furthermore, this research laid the scientific and technical foundations for engineering novel, ultra-acid-resistant stormwater materials that leverages the pH-resistance of geopolymer gels stabilized by cationic metals and the preferential formation of zeolitic structures that form in AACs. Together, this effort addressed the societal need for more resilient and sustainable infrastructure, while balancing goals related to ecological protection and environmental sustainability by creating the fundamental knowledge needed to ensure the long-term durability of innovative AAC materials. Finally, this project provided support for the education and training of next-generation thought leaders that will continue to advance the research and development of novel cement chemistries that further improve the sustainability and long-term durability of civil infrastructure.
